titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the James Fitzgerald Papers, 1905-1992, in the Archives of American Art AAA.fitzjame
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Judy Ng
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the creation of the finding aid for this collection was provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 213922

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-03-09T15:31-0400

did.abstract: The papers of painter James Fitzgerald measure 4.6 linear feet and date from 1905 to 1992. Found within the papers are biographical materials; personal and business correspondence, including fifty-one letters from Rockwell Kent; personal business records; writings; artwork consisting of drawings and 21 sketchbooks; printed material, including a scrapbook of clippings and catalogs; and photographs of Fitzgerald, his family and friends, and his work.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers were donated in 1991 by Fitzgerald’s literary executors, Anne and Edgar Hubert. Two additional sketchbooks were donated in 2014 by the chairman of the James Fitzgerald Legacy, Robert L. Stahl.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was fully processed by Jean Fitzgerald in 1994. A finding aid was prepared by Judy Ng in 2014 with funding provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: James Fitzgerald papers, 1905-1992. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The James Fitzgerald papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Painter James Fitzgerald (1899-1971) lived and worked in Monterey, California and Monhegan, Maine and is known for his watercolors of seascapes, animals, and nature.

Born in Milton, Massachusetts, Fitzgerald studied from 1919 to 1923 at the Massachusetts School of Art and from 1923 to 1924 at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts School with Philip Hale, Leslie P. Thompson, and Edmund C. Tarbell. From 1923 to 1928, Fitzgerald took a break from his art studies to travel, sailing and crewing on fishing ships and freighters on the coasts of northern America. During a trip along the West coast in 1928, his travels brought him to Monterey, California where he established a studio and met and became associated with a group including John Cage, Martha Graham, E. F. Ricketts, and John Steinbeck.

From 1936 to 1942, Fitzgerald taught painting in California, then sold his studio the following year to settle in the artists’ colony at Monhegan, Maine, which he had first visited in 1923. From 1944 to 1971, Fitzgerald made annual trips to Mt. Katahdin and also formed friendships with other Monhegan residents, including Rockwell Kent and Anne and Edgar Hubert. Fitzgerald died suddenly on the Irish island of Arranmore Ireland, where he had traveled to paint in 1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of painter James Fitzgerald measure 4.6 linear feet and date from 1905 to 1992. Found within the papers are biographical materials; personal and business correspondence, including fifty-one letters from Rockwell Kent; personal business records; writings; artwork consisting of drawings and 21 sketchbooks; printed material, including a scrapbook of clippings and catalogs; and photographs of Fitzgerald, his family and friends, and his work.

Biographical materials include certificates, military records, and identification cards and passports. Correspondence is with collectors and friends, including Monhegan residents Anne and Edgar Hubert, Grace Sullivan, and Rockwell Kent. Personal business records include banking, tax, and estate records. Writings consist of Fitzgerald's notebook and notes, essays and recollections of Fitzgerald by friends, and Calvin Hennig's notes on a 1984 posthumous exhibition catalog.

There are loose drawings and 21 sketchbooks of Fitzgerald's artwork. Printed material includes clippings, a clippings scrapbook, exhibition catalogs, and a five-minute video recording describing the holdings of Anne and Edgar Hubert's Fitzgerald art collection. Photographs are of Fitzgerald, his friends and family, residents, travel snapshots, and photographs and slides of his artwork.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 7 series.

list.item: Series 3: Personal Business Records, 1948-1972 (0.5 linear feet; Box 2)
Series 6: Printed Material, 1923-1989 (0.2 linear feet; Box 4)
Series 7: Photographic Material, 1905-1992 (0.3 linear feet; Box 4)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical materials include copies of Fitzgerald's birth certificate, honorary discharge papers from the Marines, a social security card, and 2 passports from 1964 and 1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 5, Folder 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes incoming and outgoing letters to collectors and friends, including Anne and Edgar Hubert and Grace Sullivan. Notable are fifty-one letters from Rockwell Kent primarily discussing Fitzgerald's and Kent's interests and property in Monhegan, Maine. Letters from Monhegan Associates, Inc., a group devoted to preservation of Monhegan Island, contains by-laws, minutes of meetings, and newsletters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: With the exception of correspondence with Rockwell Kent and Monhegan Associates Inc., letters are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal business records include bank statements, cancelled checks, income tax and insurance records, receipts, some for gilding work and art supplies, and estate records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings include Fitzgerald's notebook, his notes on gilding and various topics, an essay about the ship, "The Elizabeth Howard," an essay by an unidentified author about Fitzgerald's and Rockwell Kent's friendship, and essays on Fitzgerald. Also in the series are index cards containing notes for a catalog of the 1984 exhibition, "James Fitzgerald," by Calvin Hennig . There are also interviews and accompanying transcripts that relate friends' recollections of Fitzgerald. Recordings are on 4 sound cassettes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged as 2 subseries.

did.unittitle: Essay, On the Friendship Between Fitzgerald and Rockwell Kent, by Anne Hubert
Essay, "James Fitzgerald," by Elisabeth Levi de Montezinos
Essay, "Recollections of James Fitzgerald," by Marjorie Lloyd
Essay, "James Fitzgerald and Mt. Katahdin," Author Unknown
Gallery Talk, "Recollections of the Artist James Fitzgerald," by Anne Hubert
Interview, Sandra Dickson and Harry Bone on Fitzgerald
Interview Transcript, Doris Young on Fitzgerald
Gallery Proof, James Fitzgerald Catalog, William A. Farnsworth Library and Art Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 5, Folder 1.

did.unittitle: Oversized Gallery Proof from Box 3, Folder 20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork consists of 14 drawings and 21 sketchbooks dating from 1921-1969. Sketchbooks include renderings of Monhegan seascapes, and travel sketches from Mt. Katahdin, London, and Ireland.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type; sketchbooks are in numerical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversize material housed in Box 5, Folder 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes clippings and a clippings scrapbook that includes four letters and a sampling of exhibition catalogs. There are also exhibition announcements and catalogs, reproductions of art work, programs, art supply catalogs, picture postcards, a brochure and geological survey maps of Mt. Katahdin, yearbook ARTGUM excerpts , and miscellaneous printed material. A videocassette, "James Fitzgerald: Paintings and Drawings from the Collection of Anne and Edgar Hubert," is narrated by Anne Hubert and produced by Eric Shambroom.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

did.unittitle: Exhibition, "Paintings and Drawings from the Collection of Anne and Edgar Hubert" at the DeCordova Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs are of Fitzgerald; his parents and siblings; his wife Pegs; friends, including actor Richard Boone, Dan Burne Jones, E. F. Ricketts, and John Steinbeck; his studios, including the Kent-Fitzgerald cottage; travel sights; the hotel in which Fitzgerald died; and objects owned and designed by Fitzgerald. Photographs and slides of artwork include portraits of servicemen drawn in 1947.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by subject matter and document type.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Artwork, Portraits of Servicemen Drawn in 1947
